On Sat, 29 May 2004 17:13:07 +0100, Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
> 1) I noticed that you don't clamp the number of species, so I was
> wondering why you made this decision. Is this because the experiments
> you compare against also do this?

XOR we're comparing against Ken's data, and he clamps the # of
species.  The Tic-Tac-Toe experiments aren't directly compared with
any other results, and none of the papers I cite besides the ones
pertaining to NEAT use speciated populations anyway.

I don't know how big a difference clamping the number of species
makes.  We thought leaving the number unclamped seemed a bit more
organic.  Perhaps it's a detriment, though.  Don't know.

> 2) You square the fitness value obtained for XOR. What is the thinking
> behind this?

It's a standard method of amplifying errors in order to make easier
distinctions between outputs that are way off the mark and those that
are only slightly off the mark.

> 3) The Tic-Tac-Toe experiment uses the "standard hyperbolic tangent"
> activation function. Again, is this to give a more accurate comparison
> with other experiments?

No.  It was a somewhat arbitrary choice.  A sigmoid activation
function could just as easily have been used.

Derek
